A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Symmetric Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand whether the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a symmetric group, we need to analyze the components of the definition of a symmetric group. The definition of a symmetric group states that it is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set \(\{1, \ldots, n\}\). This definition inherently involves the concept of a set, specifically the set \(\{1, \ldots, n\}\), which is a finite set of integers from 1 to n. A bijective self-map refers to a function that maps elements of this set to itself in a one-to-one and onto manner. Without the concept of a set, the notion of mapping elements from a collection to itself would not be meaningful, as there would be no defined collection (set) of elements to map. Therefore, the concept of a set is fundamental and necessary for the definition of a symmetric group, as it provides the structure within which the bijective functions operate.
